src/kernel.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*!
00002  * \file
00003  * \brief
00004  *  This is the main source code for the kernel. Here all important variables
00005  *  will be initialized.
00006  *
00007  *  \mainpage
00008  *  \section Overview
00009  *  In this task the goal is to get familiar with the skeleton code of the operating system.
00010  *  In addition you should write source code that handles a system call. The system call
00011  *  returns a number which identifies the version of the kernel.
00012  *
00013  *  \section Assembly
00014  *  In addition to the C code which is documented here, some low-level functionality is
00015  *  written in assembly code. The system boots up in 32-bit mode by executing the
00016  *  instructions in boot32.s. The 64-bit part of the boot sequence is contained in boot64.s
00017  *  and finally the assembly code which handles context switches is found in enter.s. This
00018  *  code, like most assembly, code is far from easy to understand. Take help from a teaching
00019  *  assistant.
00020  */
00021 #include "kernel.h"
00022 
00023 /* Note: Look in kernel.h for documentation of global variables and functions. */
00024 
00025 /* Variables */
00026 
00027 struct context
00028 saved_registers;
00029 
00030 /* Function definitions */
00031 
00032 /*! Wrapper for a byte out instruction. */
00033 inline static void
00034 outb(const short port_number, const char output_value)
00035 {
00036  __asm volatile("outb %%al,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00037 }
00038 
00039 /*! Wrapper for a word out instruction. */
00040 inline static void
00041 outw(const short port_number, const short output_value)
00042 {
00043  __asm volatile("outw %%ax,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00044 }
00045 
00046 void
00047 kprints(const char* string)
00048 {
00049  /* Loop until we have found the null character. */
00050  while(1)
00051  {
00052   register const char curr = *string++;
00053 
00054   if (curr)
00055   {
00056    outb(0xe9, curr);
00057   }
00058   else
00059   {
00060    return;
00061   }
00062  }
00063 }
00064 
00065 void
00066 kprinthex(const register long value)
00067 {
00068  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00069  register int      i;
00070 
00071  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00072     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00073     of number of source code lines. */
00074  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00075  {
00076   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00077  }
00078 }
00079 
00080 void
00081 initialize(void)
00082 {
00083  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00084 }
00085 
00086 extern void
00087 system_call_handler(void)
00088 {
00089  switch(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax)
00090  {
00091 # include "syscall.c"
00092   default:
00093   {
00094    /* No system call defined. */
00095    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR_ILLEGAL_SYSCALL;
00096   }
00097  }
00098 }
